pull.title: [WIP] refactor: remove system interference from benchmarks
pull.body:
## Goal
This PR refactors the benchmarking functions as per #1701, in order to make benchmarks more deterministic, less influenced by the environvment, and generally simpler to run. 

## Changes
- [x] (?) remove needless fixed point conversion in favor of simpler floating point divisions. abf4566dfb7f8257a11635f639c68c50d4a8b818
- [x] replace Wall-Clock Time with Per-Thread CPU Time when possible. 02a6fc449261147c3fbae68ac4703d34e261ebd1
- [x] (?) remove min/max from benchmarks as they increase execution time 10x without even being a precise measurement of variance f41048e8f4a085bd740f51bb4e7c3e4123e02113

feel free to exclude any commits from the merge, these changes ultimately reflect how I'd have refactored it if the repo was mine.

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body:
Just some quick comments:
 
>  [x] remove the number of runs (`count`) in favor of simpler cleaner approach with just number of iterations (`iter`).

I think there's a reason to have this. Some benchmarks take much longer than others, so it probably makes sense to run fewer iters for these.

>  [x]  remove `min` and `max` statistics in favor of simpler approach with just `avg`.

I think `min` and `max` are useful. For constant-time code, you can also compare `min`. And `max` gives you an idea if there were fluctuations or not.

>  [x]  remove needless fixed point conversion in favor of simpler floating point divisions.

Well, okay, that has a history; see https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/689. It's debatable if it makes sense to avoid floating point math, but as long as it doesn't get in your way here, it's a cool thing to keep it. :D
It will be useful to split your changes into meaningful and separate commits, see https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#committing-patches.

I think `min` and `max` just complicate things. let me explain:
first of all, as it is right now, they don't even measure the min and max, they just measure the min/max of the averages of all runs. aka not the absolute. Furthermore, in order to have them, one would need to run all the iterations 10 times more. benchmarks are already slow, adding this min/max slows them by 10 fold. imho it's completely unnecessary. @real-or-random

If we're going to rework this, I'd suggest using the stabilized quartiles approach from https://cr.yp.to/papers/rsrst-20250727.pdf:
* StQ1: the average of all samples between 1st and 3rd octile
* StQ2: the average of all samples between 3rd and 5th octile
* StQ3: the average of all samples between 5th and 7th octile

> I think there's a reason to have this. Some benchmarks take much longer than others, so it probably makes sense to run fewer iters for these.

right now all benchmarks are run with count=10 and fixed iters (apart from ecmult_multi which adjusts the number of iters, not count).

therefore `count` is only useful to extrapolate `min` and `max`

> Well, okay, that has a history; see #689. It's debatable if it makes sense to avoid floating point math, but as long as it doesn't get in your way here, it's a cool thing to keep it. :D

I disagree with https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/689. It overcomplicate things for the sake of not having floating point math. those divisions aren't even in the hot path, they're outside the benchmarks.

Concept NACK on removing any ability to observe variance in timing. The current min/avg/max are far from perfect, but they work fairly well in practice. Improving is welcome, but removing them is a step backwards.

> Concept NACK on removing any ability to observe variance in timing. The current min/avg/max are far from perfect, but they work fairly well in practice. Improving is welcome, but removing them is a step backwards.

what is the usefulness of measuring min/max when we are removing OS interference & thermal throttling out of the equation? min/max will be extremely close to the avg no matter how bad the benchmarked function is.

rename.to: [WIP] refactor: remove system interference from benchmarks

events.body: by the way, `gettimeofday()` is officially discouraged since 2008 in favor of `clock_gettime()`. The POSIX standard marks it as **obsolescent** but still provides the API for backward compatibility.

even though the [manual](https://linux.die.net/man/3/clock_gettime) says that `CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID` is only useful if the process is locked to a core, modern CPUs have largely [addressed this issue](https://chatgpt.com/s/dr_68b7486a05a481919d9f121d182cc0cf). So I think it is fair to compile `CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID` even though we don't have the guarantee that the user has pinned the benchmarking process to a core. The worst case scenario is a unreliable benchmark, which the current repo has anyways.

I added a line in the README.md for best practices to run the benchmarks. 

I also tried adding a function to pin the process to a core directly in C, but there's no standard POSIX compliant way to do so. There is `pthread_setaffinity_np()` on linux, where 'np' stands for 'not portable'

> > Concept NACK on removing any ability to observe variance in timing. The current min/avg/max are far from perfect, but they work fairly well in practice. Improving is welcome, but removing them is a step backwards.
> 
> what is the usefulness of measuring min/max when we are removing OS interference & thermal throttling out of the equation? min/max will be extremely close to the avg no matter how bad the benchmarked function is.

The point is exactly having a simple way of verifying that there's indeed no interference. Getting rid of sources of variance is hard to get right, and it's impossible to get a perfect solution. (This discussion shows this!) So we better have a way of spotting if something is off.

I like the stabilized quartiles idea.

> I like the stabilized quartiles idea.

tbh it scares me a bit, will see what I can do. Maybe in a future PR.

> The point is exactly having a simple way of verifying that there's indeed no interference. Getting rid of sources of variance is hard to get right, and it's impossible to get a perfect solution. (This discussion shows this!) So we better have a way of spotting if something is off.

fine, but at least let's make it optional. I don't like my benchmarks being 10 times slower just because min/max need to be computed. if I say 20'000 iterations I want it to be 20`000 iterations.

verification.payload:
tree 37c90a6d64cbf0d23e4e4ee8b97d8d53394b191b
parent b9313c6e1a6082a66b4c75777e18ca4b176fcf9d
author Claudio Raimondi <claudio.raimondi@protonmail.com> 1756824744 +0200
committer Raimo33 <claudio.raimondi@protonmail.com> 1757194658 +0200

Remove fixed point math

This function ultimately complicates the codebase for no specific practical reason. It overcomplicate things for the sake of not having floating point math. While it is valuable to avoid fp operations in the hot path, it doesn't make sense to avoid them in this cold path that's completely unrelated with libsecp256k1's core logic.

events.message:
Remove fixed point math

This function ultimately complicates the codebase for no specific practical reason. It overcomplicate things for the sake of not having floating point math. While it is valuable to avoid fp operations in the hot path, it doesn't make sense to avoid them in this cold path that's completely unrelated with libsecp256k1's core logic.

verification.payload:
tree 2fcf1e6866c7721aad280cc73a71a1d1fa3ef6bb
parent e78de1ad51f535d12ed26b61d9c84323074ad63c
author Raimo33 <claudio.raimondi@protonmail.com> 1757195157 +0200
committer Raimo33 <claudio.raimondi@protonmail.com> 1757195157 +0200

Add more precise clocks

Currently, the benchmarks have the following limitations:

1.  **Limited Precision:** Microsecond resolution is insufficient for modern CPUs where cryptographic operations can complete in hundreds of nanoseconds. Requiring a lot of iterations to get an acceptable result
2.  **System Interference:** Wall-clock time is affected by:
    *   OS scheduler interrupts and context switches
    *   Other running processes competing for CPU time
    *   Power management and frequency scaling
    *   Thermal throttling
    *   Shared caches between cores
4.  **Non-deterministic:** Results depend on system load, making comparisons unreliable
5.  **Overhead:** System call overhead affects measurement accuracy
6.  **Branch Predictor**: the branch predictor could be 'trained' on past runs.
7.  **Lack of comparison**: elapsed time doesn't provide a stable, reliable metric for team-wide performance discussions and comparisons, unlike cpu cycle count.

This commit addresses 2.1 and 2.2 by replacing the discouraged 'gettimeofday()' in favor of the more reliable 'clock_gettime()' when possible.

events.message:
Add more precise clocks

Currently, the benchmarks have the following limitations:

1.  **Limited Precision:** Microsecond resolution is insufficient for modern CPUs where cryptographic operations can complete in hundreds of nanoseconds. Requiring a lot of iterations to get an acceptable result
2.  **System Interference:** Wall-clock time is affected by:
    *   OS scheduler interrupts and context switches
    *   Other running processes competing for CPU time
    *   Power management and frequency scaling
    *   Thermal throttling
    *   Shared caches between cores
4.  **Non-deterministic:** Results depend on system load, making comparisons unreliable
5.  **Overhead:** System call overhead affects measurement accuracy
6.  **Branch Predictor**: the branch predictor could be 'trained' on past runs.
7.  **Lack of comparison**: elapsed time doesn't provide a stable, reliable metric for team-wide performance discussions and comparisons, unlike cpu cycle count.

This commit addresses 2.1 and 2.2 by replacing the discouraged 'gettimeofday()' in favor of the more reliable 'clock_gettime()' when possible.

verification.payload:
tree f072af2cbba36b66a34cd2bcf5df429fdea0c7eb
parent ffc71f14090e2762ffce3343b7db5666ddddb8a9
author Claudio Raimondi <claudio.raimondi@protonmail.com> 1757010933 +0200
committer Raimo33 <claudio.raimondi@protonmail.com> 1757195771 +0200

Remove min/max from benchmarks

min/max attempt to measure the variation of the benchmarks across multiple runs, right now every benchmark is executed 'iter' * 'count' times, where 'count' is fixed at '10' for every benchmark. Currently this results in a 10x slower benchmark just to measure the min/max of the averages of all runs, which is not the absolute. Also these min/max are not realistic, as the 10 runs are executed one after the other, with the branch predictor hot from the previous run. This commit removes support for min/max altogether, leaving just avg. Variance can be measured manually with an external script that launches the program in a loop. That way, the branch predictor issue is addressed naturally.

events.message:
Remove min/max from benchmarks

min/max attempt to measure the variation of the benchmarks across multiple runs, right now every benchmark is executed 'iter' * 'count' times, where 'count' is fixed at '10' for every benchmark. Currently this results in a 10x slower benchmark just to measure the min/max of the averages of all runs, which is not the absolute. Also these min/max are not realistic, as the 10 runs are executed one after the other, with the branch predictor hot from the previous run. This commit removes support for min/max altogether, leaving just avg. Variance can be measured manually with an external script that launches the program in a loop. That way, the branch predictor issue is addressed naturally.

 set(CMAKE_C_EXTENSIONS OFF)
+# Enable POSIX features while maintaining ISO C compliance
+add_compile_definitions(_POSIX_C_SOURCE=200112L) #needed for `clock_gettime()` in bench.c
comments.body: we'll only need this in the benchmarks. Can you define it at the top of `bench.c`?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -159,6 +159,8 @@ Benchmark
 ------------
 If configured with `--enable-benchmark` (which is the default), binaries for benchmarking the libsecp256k1 functions will be present in the root directory after the build.
 
+For an accurate benchmark, it is strongly recommended to pin the process to a dedicated CPU core and to disable CPU frequency scaling.
comments.body: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/46369583f3a99d2b403349790f8b26dbc28de132/src/bench/bench_bitcoin.cpp#L94 may be useful

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,30 +7,63 @@
 #ifndef SECP256K1_BENCH_H
 #define SECP256K1_BENCH_H
 
+#if defined(_WIN32)
+# include <windows.h>
+#else
+# include <time.h>
+# include <sys/time.h>
comments.body: Do we need both?
and in practice?

How is this diff an improvement?
  - The pointer cast is a no-op.
  - `LL` is not needed.
This could be DRYed more. Maybe it's a good idea to print to the user which clock method is used.
What's the rationale for the change on Windows?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,30 +7,63 @@
 #ifndef SECP256K1_BENCH_H
 #define SECP256K1_BENCH_H
 
+#if defined(_WIN32)
+# include <windows.h>
+#else
+# include <time.h>
+# include <sys/time.h>
comments.body: yes, one for `gettimeofday()` and one for `clock_gettime()`. they don't conflict.
see https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1732#issuecomment-3246579226

yes, I tried everything you mentioned.

removing redundancy here can be done by just using the ifdefs for the constant, but you'd need a different path for the last fallback. the last case uses tv, not ts.

I tried issuing warnings with `#warning` to tell the user about the precision of the clock but it's not compatible with c90.

previously wall-clock times.
now per-process cpu time.
you're right. removed.

> I tried issuing warnings with `#warning` to tell the user about the precision of the clock but it's not compatible with c90.

What I had in mind is printing the warning out at runtime.

comments.body: I think then it could be slightly more portable to include only what we'll use.
Okay, sorry. I was aware of the comment in the issue, but a future reader of the code comment will not. So what I'm trying to say is that the code comment can be improved.
Added comment and link to chatgpt deepsearch. might not be very professional but it includes the full analysis and lots of citations.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,30 +7,63 @@
 #ifndef SECP256K1_BENCH_H
 #define SECP256K1_BENCH_H
 
+#if defined(_WIN32)
+# include <windows.h>
+#else
+# include <time.h>
+# include <sys/time.h>
comments.body:
just tried. unfortunately the macros to detect wether `gettimeofday()` or `clock_gettime()` is needed are defined in the `time.h` header. so the only viable solution is:

```c
#include <time.h>
#if !defined(CLOCK_PROCESS_CPUTIME_ID) && !defined(CLOCK_MONOTONIC) && !defined(CLOCK_REALTIME)
#  include <sys/time.h>
#endif
```

which every LLM tells me is 'inherently unreliable' and can lead to portability issues.

> 'Including sys/time.h on modern POSIX systems that already have time.h and clock_gettime doesn’t hurt, and ensures gettimeofday is available if needed.'

> 'Trying to skip it adds complexity with almost no benefit.'
good suggestion. done.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -30,6 +30,8 @@ set(${PROJECT_NAME}_LIB_VERSION_AGE 0)
 #=============================
 set(CMAKE_C_STANDARD 90)
 set(CMAKE_C_EXTENSIONS OFF)
+# Enable POSIX features while maintaining ISO C compliance
+add_compile_definitions(_POSIX_C_SOURCE=200112L) #needed for `clock_gettime()` in bench.c
comments.body: that was my initial setup. but it doesn't work because it has to be before *any* include. I added it to the `src/CMakeLists.txt` targeting only the benchmarks.

comments.diff_hunk:

 ------------
 If configured with `--enable-benchmark` (which is the default), binaries for benchmarking the libsecp256k1 functions will be present in the root directory after the build.
 
+For an accurate benchmark, it is strongly recommended to pin the process to a dedicated CPU core and to disable CPU frequency scaling.
comments.body: This will be more reliable at best, but not more "accurate", since it doesn't reflect actual usage.
